metadata.description_id: Setiap case berisi satu konteks dengan satu pertanyaan yang diformulasikan dalam tiga cara berbeda (original + 2 paraphrase). Model menerima konteks yang sama tapi pertanyaan yang berbeda. Tujuan: mengukur apakah jawaban model stabil atau berubah hanya karena wording pertanyaan berubah.

cases.context: As query parameters are not a fixed part of a path, they can be optional and can have default values. But when you want to make a query parameter required, you can just not declare any default value.
cases.ground_truth: By not declaring any default value for the parameter.

variants.label: original
variants.question: How do you make a query parameter required in FastAPI?

variants.label: paraphrase_1
variants.question: What is the way to force a query parameter to be mandatory in FastAPI?

variants.label: paraphrase_2
variants.question: In FastAPI, how can a query parameter be made non-optional?

annotation.catatan: Ketiga formulasi menanyakan hal yang sama dengan kata kunci berbeda: required/mandatory/non-optional. Model yang konsisten harus menjawab 'tidak mendeklarasikan default value' untuk ketiganya.
annotation.red_flag_jika: Salah satu paraphrase memicu jawaban yang menyebut cara lain seperti menggunakan Required dari Pydantic atau menggunakan Path().

cases.context: You can declare the type of a path parameter in the function, using standard Python type annotations. In this case, item_id is declared to be an int. This will give you editor support inside of your function, with error checks, completion, etc. Notice that the value your function received (and returned) is 3, as a Python int, not a string '3'.
cases.ground_truth: The function will receive the value as a Python int, not as a string.

variants.label: original
variants.question: What type does FastAPI pass to the function when a path parameter is declared as int?

variants.label: paraphrase_1
variants.question: If a path parameter is typed as int, what Python type will the function receive?

variants.label: paraphrase_2
variants.question: When you annotate a path parameter with int, what is the type of the value inside the function?

annotation.catatan: Pertanyaan menguji apakah model memahami type conversion FastAPI. Semua variant harus menghasilkan jawaban yang menyebut Python int, bukan string.
annotation.red_flag_jika: Salah satu variant memicu jawaban yang menyebut tipe lain atau tidak menyebut perbedaan int vs string sama sekali.

cases.context: In the HTTP protocol, you can communicate to each path using one or more of these methods. When building APIs, you normally use these specific HTTP methods to perform a specific action: POST to create data, GET to read data, PUT to update data, DELETE to delete data. So, in OpenAPI, each of the HTTP methods is called an operation.
cases.ground_truth: PUT is used to update data.

variants.label: original
variants.question: According to the documentation, what HTTP method is used to update data?

variants.label: paraphrase_1
variants.question: Which HTTP method should be used when you want to update existing data?

variants.label: paraphrase_2
variants.question: What is the correct HTTP method for data modification according to the provided context?

annotation.catatan: Jawaban yang benar adalah PUT. Paraphrase_2 menggunakan kata 'modification' yang bisa memicu PATCH dari training knowledge model.
annotation.red_flag_jika: Paraphrase_2 memicu jawaban PATCH atau 'PUT or PATCH' — model menggunakan prior knowledge untuk melengkapi jawaban.

cases.context: When you declare other function parameters that are not part of the path parameters, they are automatically interpreted as query parameters. As they are part of the URL, they are naturally strings. But when you declare them with Python types (in the example above, as int), they are converted to that type and validated against it.
cases.ground_truth: They are converted to that type and validated against it.

variants.label: original
variants.question: What happens to query parameters declared with Python types in FastAPI?

variants.label: paraphrase_1
variants.question: How does FastAPI process query parameters that have type annotations?

variants.label: paraphrase_2
variants.question: What does FastAPI do when a query parameter is given a Python type hint?

annotation.catatan: Model harus menyebut konversi tipe DAN validasi untuk semua variant. Hanya menyebut salah satu berarti inkonsistensi parsial.
annotation.red_flag_jika: Satu variant menyebut konversi saja, variant lain menyebut validasi saja — jawaban parsial yang tidak konsisten.

cases.context: FastAPI generates a schema with all your API using the OpenAPI standard for defining APIs. A schema is a definition or description of something. Not the code that implements it, but just an abstract description. This schema definition includes your API paths, the possible parameters they take.
cases.ground_truth: The schema definition includes your API paths and the possible parameters they take.

variants.label: original
variants.question: What does the OpenAPI schema generated by FastAPI include?

variants.label: paraphrase_1
variants.question: What information is contained in the FastAPI-generated OpenAPI schema?

variants.label: paraphrase_2
variants.question: What are the contents of the schema that FastAPI creates using the OpenAPI standard?

annotation.catatan: Ini adalah case yang sama dengan clean_007. Dipakai kembali untuk consistency eval karena jawabannya sudah diketahui dari clean case.
annotation.red_flag_jika: Model menambahkan response bodies, authentication, atau detail lain yang tidak ada di konteks untuk salah satu variant.

cases.context: Let's say you only have a single item body parameter from a Pydantic model Item. By default, FastAPI will then expect its body directly. But if you want it to expect a JSON with a key item and inside of it the model contents, as it does when you declare extra body parameters, you can use the special Body parameter embed.
cases.ground_truth: By default, FastAPI expects the body directly, without wrapping it in a key.

variants.label: original
variants.question: What is the default behavior of FastAPI when receiving a single Pydantic model as a body parameter?

variants.label: paraphrase_1
variants.question: How does FastAPI handle the request body when there is only one Pydantic model parameter?

variants.label: paraphrase_2
variants.question: When a single body parameter is declared in FastAPI, what does it expect from the incoming request by default?

annotation.catatan: Kunci jawaban adalah kata 'directly' — FastAPI expects body directly tanpa wrapping. Model yang tidak menyebut ini berarti jawabannya tidak presisi.
annotation.red_flag_jika: Salah satu variant memicu penjelasan tentang embed tanpa ditanya, atau menyebut bahwa FastAPI selalu membungkus body dalam sebuah key.
